div.p: THE ROUND-HEADS CATECHISME: OR The New ••• Catechising the Anabaptists Puritans, Seperatists, and well-affected under the name of Round-Heads.
With their joynt Answer to the same.
LONDON, Printed in the Yeare of our Lord, 1643.

sp.speaker: Answer.
sp.p: Round-Head.

p.hi: Are you all of that name?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Our backbiters, and
slanderers, in our infamy, wherein, we were made wonderlings to worldy-wise, a jeering-stocke to fooles, and inheritors of the scorne, and reproch of all the rabble of the Antichristian Kingdom of darknesse.

p.hi: How came you to be all of that name?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Because our backbiters and slanderers would have it so, as others that will not answer for a Child except they may have the name.

p.hi: VVas it without your fathers consent?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Yea.

sp.speaker: Q.
sp.p: VVould your Fa: then have had you called Anabaptists, Separatists, Puritants &c?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No, but our backbiters and slanderers, were different about them, but agreed on the name Round-head for us all.

p.hi: VVhat did your backbiters, and slanderers, then against you?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
Their practises did promise three things to our shame: First, that they will make us as odious as they can: Secondly, that they will
worke our destructiō, if they can: Thirdly, they wish GOD would dam them, if they do not what they can to destroy us.

p.hi: Doe you not think that you may beleeve these premises and feare their threatnings?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
We doubt not but they intend to performe all their wicked promises, and doe what they can against us; but we beleeve God, who have promised to deliver us; and therfore we will by his grace, not feare them that can but kill the body, but we pray
God if it be his will, not to dam them, as they ignorantly wish; but overcome them by his love, and keepe them from damnation, for his glory, & their comfort.

p.hi: But your enemies are many in number, and great in power, and are violently bent against you, how shall you escape?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
If God be our friend, as he hath promised, and we beleeve, whom shall we feare; for neither Achitophell, nor Iudas, the Irish Rebells, nor mad men in the North, the Cavaliers, nor Lordly Prelates
with all their strength, although as great as the seaven headed beast can make it, can hurt us.

p.hi: But what if the King be your enemy, will you not feare him?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
We are taught to honor and obey him, and also to pray for him, as Gods chiefe Magistrate and steward over us all, which by Gods grace we do, and purpose constantly to do; in which consideration, we have no cause to feare his Majesty, for can we think he will harme us, if we
doe well. 1. Peter, 3.13. Rom. 13.3.

p.hi: Can nothing hurt you, what strange creaturs are you.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Persecution cannot for it is out livery or cullets to shew whose souldiers we are and under whom we fight; the way to hurt us, is to let us have ease, for we are as Cammamill, the more it is trod on, they say, the sweter it smels and the better it growes.

p.hi:
But will your confidence hold thinke you, will not the feare of prisons, Pillories, losse
of eares, hanging, burning, or other torments bring downe your courage.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: If it were of our owne making and set upon our owne sandy foundation no dout but it must needs come downe, but if our God have made our confidence and founded it on the rock and chiefe corner stone Iesus Christ, we doubt not but through his strength it will stand firme as Mount Sion that cannot be remooved.

p.hi:
But I heare his Majesty conceives you are his enemies,
& plot mischiefe against him.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: No doubt his Majesty may so conceive of us, beleeving those that give false information of us, but if his Majesty read his Cronicles, he shall finde us as innocent, and harmelesse as Mordecai, and the Iewes whom Haman got commission to destroy, as the Prelats and Papists would do us.

p.hi:
VVhat is the reason they tax you with nothing but your private meetings & preaching in Tubs, and not baptizing your Children, and not coming
to Church, and the like?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Because they cannot tax us with publick ryotous combustions, drunken quarrells, nor trayterous laying Tubs of Gun powder under Parl: so that they through Gods goodnesse, as Daniels enemies know, that they shall finde nothing against us, except concerning the law of our God.

p.hi: But they say, you preach in tubs and hollow trees, is that true or no?

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
I say to you, as Phillip to Nathaniell, come and see;
but they do not tell you, they saw, and heard us preach in Tubs; for they be none of our Auditors, that speak so of us: but because their preists preach in Pulpits, they thinke it must be in some round thing, else tis no preaching: and in houses, Tubs are more frequent then pulpits.

p.hi: But they certifie his Majesty, that you are the great disturbers of the Peace, & the cause of this unnaturall VVar, and so destructive in his Kingdome.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p:
If our owne m • uth or pe • justifie us, it is nothing; therefo • e we are willing to have out actiōs tryed by the unerring rule of the word of God. Obedience, whereunto we hope is not distructive to a Kingdom, although the Prelats, as Hamon, wou • d worke our distruction; because we dare not in conscience bow to them as Mordecai durst not to that agagit, Hester. 3.2. But I hope you cannot forget, that the Prelats were the first beginners of these troubles, by urging their Service-booke upon the Scots; for resisting whereof, they stirred up his Maiesty by relation, to raise an army against them, which fire of theirs then kindled,
their practise have bin to their power, to blow and encrease ever since, and we hope, you will not say, that we help forward their wicked designes, for we oppose them, & all their Ministers, and their way, and entrance into office, and Ministry, to be all Anti-Christian: and therefore we, especially Anabaptists, and Seperatists, as we will not heare them, so neither shall they tast of our tithes, or offrings, till they aprove themselves the ministers of Christ, by his word, and then we promise to pay them all, for time to come, and make up what they thinke is behind; and that we by the help of God although we be weake in regard of human
learning, yet we will at any time account it our priviledge to dispute the cause with any of them, before either godly Magistrats, or Christians from the word of God, although indeed our Brother Puritan and vvell affected, are not altogether cleere for this but we conceive, they cannot aprove themselves Ministers for Christ nor for his People but for mony for tithes, for honors, pleasures and ease, they have mens Persons in admiration, for these advantages, and so with fained words, they make Marchan lise of them: but if there be a flock a hundred miles distant that have a warmer fleece, and sweeter milke, to cloth and feed,
I meane a greater benefice, then let who will looke to their flock, over whom indeed, not Christ, but Antichrist made them overseers. Whereas, our Ministers of Christ, if we give them nothing, they will aske us nothing; but will worke vvith their own hands, according to Paules example and rule. Acts, the 20.34.35. and vvill not only teach us, but also Minister to our vvants i • vve have more need and count it their happinesse vvhen they can do Gods people either spirituall or temporall good, and if you say they knovv not the originalls nor the tongues, & have not the vvrightings of the Fathers, nor long time of study: and
therefore they cannot be the Ministers of Christ. We ansvver, Christ have promised to teach them, and they can study as vvell at their callings as antichrists Ministers in their studies, or great Libraries. Else judge the tree by the fruit, the vvorkeman by the vvorke see if there be more Idolaters, adulterers drunkards, theeves, extortioners covetous, blasphemers, or liers, amongst us or them. Although vve haue no cause to bo • st for if vve in the least be free of any of these sins, no thanke to us but to him that vvork's the same againe if they preach Christ vvith Paule, they vvill vvith him acknovvledge themselves our servants for
his sake. Then if they be our servants for his sake, then they vvill not require vvages of us. Then tis for the vv • ges sake, Christs Ministers have a holy scorne to come to u • for vvag • s for their vvorke.

Or much lesse to bargaine for any, ••• hough indeed his people know that it is their duty not to see any poor minister of Christ want necessaries, his law is a law of love not of ungratefulnesse to the messengers of Christ, whome you may know by these markes, 1. They come
in by the door, & not climbe up any other way, Ioh. 10.1.2.2 They have his hand in his word to their testimony, which who so hath we will acknowledge to be the minister of Christ, thus master Newter I am bold to tell you, that I hope if his Majesty or any of his freinds did know the truth of us, they would not thinke so hardly of us.

sp.speaker: Master Newter,
sp.p: Indeed I thinke so, but what shall you doe in this case.

sp.speaker: Anabaptist.
sp.p: I will confere with my brethren and speake with you againe.

sp.speaker: Seperatist.
sp.p: What is best to do herein.

sp.speaker: Anabaptist.
sp.p:
For my part, I conceive it is best to follow Hesters example, if not fast three dayes & 3. nights, yet to seeke God in our severall Churches or Assemblies in an extrordinary māner, as she did, seeing we are in extrordinary danger as she then was and her
people.

sp.speaker: Puritane
sp.p: It were very good, but alas we fea • e if our enemies should know it they would pull downe our houses over our heads as they have done by some already.

sp.speaker: Anabaptist
sp.p: If our wayes please the Lord he will make our Enemies at peace with us.

sp.speaker: Seperatist
sp.p: But how comes this emnity.

sp.speaker: Anabaptist
sp.p:
Truly some thinke from
our selves by being so private in our meetings, if it be so brethren, out affliction is Iust upon us for we conceive it fit to let all heare that will and the more come to heare us the more wellcome, how say you brethren do not you allow the same to which all answer yes, then brethren we will print the same, that they may know our minds, for it may be they do not think so, the answer of all 'tis our desire; for they are flesh of our flesh, and bone of our bone, of the lost stock of Adam as
we were, and are by nature. And we were as they yet are blind and could not see our lost condition, as they now cānot till Iesus Christ found us and brought us into his way, and now let us in love pray him to bring them in to his way also, and then they will walke with us in the same, & we with them in all godly mutuall love and kind behaviour, and car • age each to other, and so our God shall have glory andour our selves comfort and edification.

For truly they that hate us most
and most cruelly persecute us, do not more by us then we our selves the best of us naturally did and would do any that love God and his wayes. But if as our Saviour commanded us we • et our light shine before men, then they seing our good worke will be sooner wonne to be • n love with our vvayes then by hearing our good words and so glorify our father vvhich is in heaven. Then vve returne to you our brethren according to the flesh to certify you that as we are bound to obey God in walking according as he requireth us in his w • rd, so we are not onely content that where as you may conceive, that we meete for evill practises, you
would come and see but also to report of us and do by us according as you see our practice deserve, for God teacheth us, that they that do truth are willing that their deeds should be made manifest Iohn the 3.20. Whereas they that do evill hate the light that should manifest their actions, and when you see our actions and practis to be good wheras yet you by report Iudge it to be evill we doubt not but God will move you to speake of us and do by us according as you shall see, not according as you have heard at the report of slanderers.

For indeed we beleve there are many that speake evill of our way that would not if they knew the
truth of it, and so they speake evill of what they know not, there fore freinds we are resolved to do what God require of us, and not to hinder any that would behold our practises, seeing our God sayes who shall harme us, if we do well, and therefore seeing that God requires of us of us if we be converted to strengthen our brethren, and seing againe, that the hearts of Kings are in the hands of God, as the rivers of waters, and he turnes them which vvay soever it pleaseth him and seeing he hath said, vvhen a mans vvayes please the Lord he maketh his ene • ies at peace with him; and againe seing some of us have seen, that God hatd verified
this truth in some of our experience some that have come by their ovvne confussion, intending our hurt, God hath met them then, for their and our good; and thus vvhen vve desire to cleere us, before God and all men, that vve in love to our brethren, and all men and vvomen in the vvorld vve desire and endeavoure to please God and do good to all, that if they yet hate us, it may after truly be said they hated us without a cause.

div.p: THen Brethren, let us not avenge our selves, but remember the Counsell of Christ; if thine enemy hunger, feed him: if he thirst, give him drinke. And that of Paule, be not overcome of evill, but overcome evill with good. then whatsoever their tounge say, their conscience will cleere us. Thus when all men and woman see that our practises are according to the rule of God, and his perfect law of love, they will say the aspertions that have been laid upon us, have bin without a cause Then 〈1+ pages missing〉

WHo verily beleeveth that if he might be heard that God would shew by him a way of deliverance of this City and places yet unplundered in a way very acceptable to God and acc • ptable to all his Majesties subjects, except such as are p • lp • ble oposers of King & Parliamen • , if they can but beleve that God can declare secrets by them that feare him, as well as reveale his secrets
to them that feare him Psal. the 25.14. and that he will not only make it apeare possible but also very probable and very cheape.

But remember the woman that would not come to Christ till all her money was spent upon Physitians but doe not follow her example but remember sometimes the waters of Iordā are beter then Abana and Pharphar to clense Naaman, somtimes Davids, sling thē Sauls swoard and coat of male, and gidions Lampes pitchers
and Rams hornes beter then all the weapons and strength of the host of Median.
Who can also informe any honest man in his honest cause what to do in most common causes or suits of Law and shew how he may do for his best advantage against his adversary for nothing
The author dwell's in Angell alley in whit-Chappell.
Also he will be thankefull to you, if you will buy of him, good peniworths of Sugar, Spices or small wares.
